Chapter 22: The Five Precepts, Part 5
SubhÅ«ti said:
World-Honored One!
What kind of people can take the Three Refuges?
What kind of people cannot take the Three Refuges?
Good man!
If people believe in causes, believe in effects, believe in the truths, and believe in attaining the Way, such people can take the Three Refuges;
If people have a sincere mind, believe unshakably, draw close to the Three Jewels, and accept the teachings of good friends, such people can take the Three Refuges;
The upÄsaka precepts are also like this.
If one can contemplate the immeasurable merits and rewards of the upÄsaka precepts, and destroy immeasurable evil dharmas,
Sentient beings are boundless, and suffering is the same. It is difficult to obtain a human body;
Although one may obtain a human body, it is difficult to have complete faculties;
Although one may possess all faculties, it is difficult to develop faith;ğŸ”½Although one may develop faith, it is difficult to encounter a good friend;
Although one may encounter a good friend, it is difficult to attain mastery;
Although one may attain mastery, all dharmas are impermanent.
If I now create evil karma, due to this evil karma I will obtain the evil retribution of body and mind in the two periods of time. For this reason, the evil of body, speech, and mind is my enemy.
Even if the evil of the three karmas does not result in evil retribution, one should not create evil in the present.

This evil of the three karmas, in the present, can give rise to bad form and so forth. At the time of death, one will have regrets. For this reason, I take refuge in the Three Jewels and observe the eight precepts, distancing myself from all evil and unwholesome karma.
The wise should contemplate that precepts are of two kinds:
First, worldly precepts; second, ultimate precepts.
If one does not take precepts based on the Three Jewels, these are called worldly precepts. These precepts are not firm, like colored pigments without glue;
Therefore, I first take refuge in the Three Jewels and then receive the precepts.
Whether for a lifetime or for one day and one night, namely the precepts of an upÄsaka or the eight precepts of the upavÄsa.
As for the worldly precepts, they cannot destroy past evil karma;
But by receiving the precepts of taking refuge in the Three Jewels, one can destroy it. Even if one commits grave offenses, one does not lose the precepts.
Why is this?
It is because of the power of the precepts.

There are two kinds of people who commit offenses together. One has received the precepts, and the other has not. For one who has received the precepts, the offense is grave, while for one who has not received the precepts, the offense is light.
Why is this?
It is because one violates the Buddha's words.
There are two kinds of offenses:
First, offenses that are grave by nature, and second, offenses that are grave due to prohibitions.
These two kinds of offenses also have degrees of gravity.
Some people can make grave offenses light and light offenses grave, like Aá¹…gulimÄla who received the worldly precepts, and the IrÄpatra dragon who received the precepts based on the meaning;
Angulimala violated a grave nature precept but did not receive a grave offense, while the dragon Elapattra violated a light prohibitive precept and received a grave offense.
Therefore, some people turn grave offenses into light ones, and light offenses into grave ones. Therefore, one should not attain the same fruits by the same precepts.
The worldly precepts also have no killing and no stealing, and the principled precepts also have no killing and no stealing;
Up to not drinking alcohol, it is the same.

Thus, the worldly precepts are fundamentally impure, the acceptance is impure, the adornment is impure, the contemplation is impure, the mindful thought is impure, and the karmic retribution is impure, so they cannot be called the ultimate precepts, but only worldly precepts;
Therefore, I should accept the principled precepts.
Good man!

In the future world, sentient beings will be eight zhang tall and have a lifespan of eighty-four thousand years. At that time, the fruits obtained from accepting the precepts will be the same as those obtained in this evil world.
Why is it so?
Because the three roots of goodness are equal.
Some say that one can only obtain precepts by killing, but this is not so!
Why is it so?

Because the precepts are obtained from all that can be killed and cannot be killed. All that can be killed and cannot be killed is immeasurable and boundless, and the fruits and rewards of the precepts are also like this, immeasurable and boundless.
Good man!
Among all kinds of giving, giving fearlessness is the best. Therefore, I say that the five great kinds of giving are the five precepts.

Such five precepts can enable sentient beings to be free from the five kinds of fear. These five kinds of giving are easy to practice, unrestricted, and do not lose one's wealth, yet one obtains immeasurable and boundless blessings and virtues.
Apart from these five kinds of giving, one cannot attain the fruit of stream-entry, up to attaining supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

If one receives the precepts, one should know that this person will be respected and guarded by celestial beings and humans, attain great fame, and although encountering evil circumstances, the mind will be free from sorrow and distress, and sentient beings will be close to and happily come to rely on [him/her].
Although the son of the elder AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada received the precepts for eight thousand gold coins, he also attained immeasurable meritorious rewards.
Good man!
Even receiving the precepts for the sake of wealth still brings benefits, let alone those who sincerely seek liberation - how could they not attain it?
Good man!
There are five wholesome dharmas that surround this precept, always causing it to increase, like the water of the Ganges.
What are the five?
First, kindness; second, compassion; third, joy; fourth, patience; fifth, faith.

If a person is able to destroy heavy wrong views and the mind is free from doubt and confusion, then one is endowed with right mindfulness, adorned with purity, with a pure basis, and free from evil thoughts and speculations.
Good man!
If a person can stay away from these five evil things, this is called upholding the precepts and staying away from all evil deeds of body, speech, and mind.
If there is someone who says that apart from the five precepts, one can transcend birth and death, there is no such possibility!
Good man!
If a person wishes to cross the great ocean of birth and death, they should wholeheartedly uphold the five precepts.
Among the five precepts, four become precepts without action in the afterlife, only the precept against sexual misconduct is difficult to sever and cannot be fulfilled;
For this reason, sexual desire is entangled, one should be wholeheartedly careful and not be negligent!
If there is someone who says:
There are immeasurable other extremely serious dharmas, why did the Buddhas of the past not establish precepts against them, but establish precepts against alcohol?
Good man!

Because of drinking alcohol, the mind of shame and conscience is destroyed, and one does not give rise to fear of the three evil destinies. For this reason, one is then unable to uphold the other four precepts. Therefore, the Buddhas of the past established precepts not to allow drinking.
If someone says, 'The TathÄgata has already said that alcohol has many faults, why is it not mentioned first in the five precepts?'
This is not so!
Why is it so?
This precept against alcohol is called a heavy prohibition, not a precept against natural evil;
The TathÄgata first established precepts against natural evil, and later established prohibitions against heavy offenses.
Good man!
The TathÄgata first spoke of the three fast days in the bright and dark fortnights, following the non-Buddhists;
The non-Buddhists always use these days to make offerings to the gods, therefore the TathÄgata spoke of the three fast days.
Good man!

Just as a curtain does not fall because it is supported by a window frame, the method of the three fast days is also like this. If sentient beings arouse the intention to uphold it, they will never fall into the three evil paths.
Good man!

If a person, when wishing to give, making offerings to the Three Jewels, sitting in meditation, cultivating goodness, reading scriptures, or making offerings to parents, should first establish a rule, thinking If I do not do this, I will punish myself,
that person's merit and virtue will increase day and night, like the flow of the Ganges River.
Thus, these five precepts have five kinds of fruits:
First, the fruit of non-action; second, the fruit of retribution; third, the fruit of the remainder; fourth, the fruit of creation; fifth, the fruit of liberation.
If there are those who fully accept and uphold the five precepts, one should know that such a person obtains these five fruits.
If an upÄsaka is always able to go out to temples and monasteries, and upon arrival, becomes close to the bhiká¹£us,
having become close, he inquires about the flavor of the Dharma;
having inquired about the Dharma, he should listen with utmost sincerity;
having listened, he accepts and upholds it, remembers it without forgetting, and is able to discern the meaning;
After discerning the meaning, they transform and educate sentient beings. This is called the upÄsaka's benefiting oneself and benefiting others.

If an upÄsaka cannot study and learn as explained above, despises bhiká¹£us, seeks faults while going to listen to the Dharma, has no respectful faith, serves non-Buddhist paths, sees their merits, and deeply believes in the sun, moon, five planets, and constellations, this upÄsaka is not called firmly abiding in the Dharma.
If an upÄsaka, although not personally committing the five evil karmas, causes others to do them, this upÄsaka is not abiding in the Dharma.

If an upÄsaka first takes others' things, promising to use them for a certain purpose, this upÄsaka is not abiding in the Dharma.ğŸ”½If an upÄsaka is in charge of official ferry crossings, taxing and selling goods, this upÄsaka is not abiding in the Dharma.
If an upÄsaka treats illnesses for a fee, treating and then selling goods, this upÄsaka is not abiding in the Dharma.
If an upÄsaka violates the official regulations and does not abide by the Dharma,
If an upÄsaka does not commit evil himself, does not instruct others to do so, and does not think of evil in his mind, he is said to abide by the Dharma.
If an upÄsaka commits offenses arising from guest afflictions and does not feel ashamed, remorseful, or repentant after committing them, he does not abide by the Dharma.
If an upÄsaka commits evil deeds for the sake of his body and life, he does not abide by the Dharma.
Even if an upÄsaka obtains a human body, if he practices non-Dharma, he is not considered a human.

If he obtains faith, is able to create merit and virtue, skillfully cultivates right mindfulness, contemplates that all dharmas are impermanent, without self or what belongs to self, has no attachment in his mind towards any dharma, sees that all dharmas are not autonomous, arise and cease, are suffering, empty, and lack tranquility;
obtains a human body, although obtaining a human body, it is difficult to possess all faculties;
Although endowed with all faculties, it is difficult to attain right view;
Although endowed with right view, it is difficult to attain faith;
Although one attains faith, it is difficult to encounter good friends;
Although one encounters good friends, it is difficult to hear the true Dharma;
Although one hears the true Dharma, it is difficult to attain acceptance and retention:
One who is able to contemplate in this way is a human being.

If a person is able to contemplate that the desire realm is impermanent, up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is all impermanent, for this reason, they do not seek the three evil destinies up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
Having contemplated in this way, they see the three inconstancies, and with an inconstant body they exchange it for a constant body:
Bowing and making offerings, coming to welcome and seeing off, personally giving, and personally performing meritorious deeds, this is called exchanging an inconstant body for a constant body.
Exchanging inconstant wealth for constant wealth:

One can use it oneself and also give it to those who are sick and on the road, to support Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and the poor and lowly. This is called exchanging impermanent wealth for permanent wealth.
Exchanging impermanent life for permanent life:

Cultivating the six remembrances, loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, realizing the four noble truths, skillfully observing birth, old age, sickness, and death, clearly believing in the fruits of good and evil karma, definitely knowing that loved ones will eventually part, all beings are not independent, not having attained the holy path, the power of birth and death is great, all worldly pleasures are always accompanied by suffering, although experiencing them, the mind is not attached, just as in the cold months seeking fire to warm oneself, although doing it, one never does evil;
Cultivating patience and the two kinds of giving to benefit beings, deeply contemplating that the nature of suffering and happiness is equal;

Whatever words they speak, their speech is gentle, skillfully transforming sentient beings, causing them to abide in accordance with the Dharma. They stay far away from bad friends, their minds are not heedless, and they do not engage in drinking alcohol, gambling, or hunting. This is called exchanging an insubstantial life for a substantial life.
Good man!

If one obtains a human body, has abundant wealth, and also obtains self-mastery, one should first make offerings to one's parents, teachers, elders, those who uphold the Dharma, and provide for those who have come from afar and those who are newly practicing, as well as the necessities for the sick.

Their speech is gentle, they have a lot of shame and humility, they do not single-mindedly believe in and respect a single virtuous person, and they see sages who uphold the precepts and have much learning, and are able to make offerings to them with dwellings, food and drink, bedding, clothing, and medicine.

Deeply believing that there are many merits in the Sangha, they cultivate and head towards the path, attaining the fruit of stream-entry, and even being able to cultivate and head towards arhatship, attaining the fruit of arhatship, and cultivating the vajra samÄdhi and the lightning samÄdhi.
Having contemplated in this way, they make equal offerings;
Having made such offerings, they attain immeasurable blessings.
Therefore, in the Deer Son SÅ«tra, I told the mother of Deer Son:
Even if one invites the Buddha and five hundred arhats, it is still not called the merit of inviting the Sangha.
If one is able to give to a single counterfeit bhiká¹£u in the Sangha, one will still attain immeasurable merit and rewards.
Why is this?

Because such a bhiká¹£u, although an evil person, has no precepts or much learning, and does not cultivate good dharmas, is still able to expound the three kinds of enlightenment, with causes and effects, and does not slander the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha treasures, upholds the unsurpassed victory banner of the TathÄgata, and has right views without error.

If a person makes offerings without seeking rewards, it is the same as making offerings to unsurpassed enlightenment, and they will fully accomplish the perfection of giving, cultivate the path to enlightenment, and be able to attain immeasurable merits in the future, benefiting both themselves and others.
They will be able to cultivate compassion and break through others' suffering, giving up their own happiness.

Even though they have not yet attained enlightenment, their minds are free from worry and regret. They enjoy practicing in accordance with the Dharma, do not seek worldly pleasures, enjoy dwelling in solitude, leave the household life to cultivate the path, and though not yet having left the household life, while living at home they are like liberated people who do not commit many evil deeds, and attain the three kinds of precepts - the precepts of precepts, the precepts of concentration, and the precepts of impurity.

There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, those who are householders, and second, those who have left the household life.
It is not difficult for bodhisattvas who have left the household life to practice in accordance with the Dharma;
It is difficult for bodhisattvas who are householders to practice in accordance with the Dharma.

Chapter 23: The Perfection of Morality from the Sutra on the UpÄsaka Precepts Good son said:
World-Honored One!
How do bodhisattvas who are heading towards enlightenment have a firm mind?
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who are firm have four qualities in full:
First, when experiencing great suffering, they will never abandon practices in accordance with the Dharma;
Second, having attained great freedom, they will always cultivate patience;
Third, even if they are poor, they will always delight in giving;
Fourth, even in the prime of their youth, they will always delight in leaving the household life.
If a bodhisattva is endowed with these four dharmas, they will progress towards enlightenment with a firm mind.
The bodhisattva, being endowed with these four dharmas, further thinks:
'This is the initial fundamental ground of the path to enlightenment, which is called morality.

Such morality is also called the initial ground, the guiding ground, the level ground, the equal ground, the ground of kindness, the ground of compassion, the Buddha's footprint, the root of all merits, and the field of merit;
For these reasons, the wise should uphold it without violating it.'
Furthermore, the wise person thinks like this:
'Morality has two fruits:
First, the bliss of the heavens, second, the bliss of enlightenment.
The wise should seek the bliss of enlightenment, not the bliss of the heavens.

' If, after receiving the precepts, one does what should not be done, thinks of what should not be thought of, is lazy and indolent, delights in sleep, thinks evil thoughts, and has evil aspirations, this is called defiling the precepts.
If, after receiving the precepts, one regrets it in one's heart, seeks the bliss of humans and gods, is very indulgent, and does not feel compassion, this is called defiling the precepts.

If one receives the precepts out of fear of poverty, fear, loss of wealth, fear of being made to work, for the sake of one's body and life, for the sake of profit and gain, or out of a loving heart, and after receiving the precepts, one gives rise to doubt, this is called defiling the precepts.
Good man!

If a person does not enjoy staying in samsara for a long time, deeply sees the faults and crimes, views the happiness of humans and gods and the suffering of AvÄ«ci Hell as equal and without distinction, has compassion for sentient beings, is fully endowed with right mindfulness, and wishes to benefit immeasurable sentient beings so that they may attain enlightenment;
In order to be fully endowed with the unsurpassed bodhi path, in order to practice according to the Dharma, one receives and upholds these precepts;
The mind is not heedless, and one is able to contemplate the bodily, verbal, and mental actions of the past, future, and present, knowing the light and knowing the heavy;
Whatever one does, one should first focus the mind on cultivating heedfulness, and after doing it and while doing it, one should also cultivate heedfulness in the same way;

If one does not know beforehand and commits an offense, one will incur a transgression. If one loses mindfulness, one will also incur a transgression. If one temporarily gives rise to afflictions, one will also incur a transgression. If one is slightly negligent, one will also incur a transgression. Such a person always regards even minor transgressions as serious, and upon reflection gives rise to remorse and a sense of shame. Frightened and distressed, one's mind is unhappy. Repenting with utmost sincerity, one gives rise to joy upon repentance. Carefully guarding and upholding the precepts, one does not dare to transgress again. This is called pure precepts.
Good son!
A wise person, having received the precepts, should contemplate three things and not engage in evil conduct:
First, for oneself; second, for the world; third, for the Dharma.
What does it mean to be for oneself?
I personally know that this is an evil matter. Knowing that committing evil karma results in such consequences, and knowing that performing good karma results in such consequences,
The evil karma one creates is not false, and one will definitely receive the fruits of evil; the good karma one creates is also not false, and one will definitely receive the fruits of good.
If these two kinds of karma are not false, then how can I deceive myself?
For this reason, after I have accepted the precepts, I should not violate them. I should uphold them with utmost sincerity. This is called acting for oneself.
What is acting for the world?
The wise observe and see that there are people in the world who attain the divine ear, divine eye, and knowledge of others' minds. If I do evil, these people will definitely see, hear, and know me;
if they see, hear, and know me, how can I not feel shame and do evil?

Furthermore, contemplating the devas who are endowed with immeasurable merit, spiritual powers, divine hearing, and divine vision, and who possess the knowledge of others' minds, can see and hear from afar, though they are near to humans, humans cannot see them. If I do evil, such devas will see, hear, and know it;
if these devas clearly see me, how can I not give rise to shame and remorse and commit offenses?
This is called the world.
What is the Dharma?

A wise person contemplates the TathÄgata's Dharma, which is pure and unstained, attains present benefits, can bring peace and transcend to the other shore, and can bring about liberation, without selecting the time.
I uphold the precepts for the sake of this Dharma. If I cannot first accept the minor precepts, how can I be able to accept the major precepts?
Having broken the minor precepts, I increase the suffering of the five existences. If I uphold them with utmost sincerity, I increase unsurpassed bliss.
The reason I have not yet attained liberation since taking on this body is truly because I have not received the precepts from the past immeasurable buddhas, the TathÄgatas.
I now receive the precepts, and in the future I will definitely encounter buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River.

Having deeply contemplated this, I give rise to great compassion and receive the precepts with utmost sincerity. Having received them, I will uphold them firmly for the sake of anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi and to benefit immeasurable sentient beings.
Good man!

Whether lay or ordained, whether taking the Three Refuges, the Eight Precepts, the Five Precepts, the complete precepts, or the incomplete precepts, whether for one day and night, one moment, or one's entire life, if one receives and upholds them with utmost sincerity, one should know that this person will attain great blessings and virtues.
Good man!

If one, after receiving the precepts, cultivates the three wholesome actions - learning much, giving, and cultivating concentration - and makes offerings to the Three Jewels, this is called adorning bodhi.

If, after receiving the precepts, one can read the TathÄgata's twelve divisions of the canon, which is called the unsurpassed great treasury of the Dharma, and diligently apply oneself with vigor, wishing to perfect the perfection of morality,
such morality, having been received in this world, will later, even if not received, become morality without action.
Good son!
There is morality that is not a pÄramitÄ, there is a pÄramitÄ that is not morality, there is morality that is a pÄramitÄ, and there is neither morality nor a pÄramitÄ.
Morality that is not a pÄramitÄ refers to the morality of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
A pÄramitÄ that is not morality refers to the pÄramitÄ of giving.

Morality that is a pÄramitÄ refers to, for example, when the ancient bodhisattvas received the body of a tortoise, for the sake of all beings, they did not move or give rise to an evil mind, even though their bodies were eaten by insects, beasts, and ants;
or like the sages who, for the sake of sentient beings, remained on the peak of Mount Sumeru for twelve years, neither rising nor moving.
The non-precepts and non-pÄramitÄs are like worldly giving.
Good son!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in the perfection of morality, who can speak of the various sufferings they endure?

If someone, having received even a small precept, is content with few desires and is unable to have compassion for suffering sentient beings, one should know that this person is unable to fully perfect the perfection of morality.

If one is able to cultivate patience, samÄdhi, wisdom, diligently practice with vigor, and delight in much learning, one should know that this person will be able to increase the perfection of morality, adorn bodhi, and realize the fruit of bodhi.
Such morality, due to the immeasurable sentient beings, immeasurable karmic rewards, and immeasurable precepts and prohibitions, adorns bodhi through these causes and conditions.
Good son!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having received the precepts, do not speak evil with the mouth, do not delight in hearing evil with the ears, do not delight in speaking of the world, nor delight in hearing about it, never let the mind dwell on evil thoughts and contemplations, and do not associate with evil friends. Therefore, it is called the pure precepts of tranquility.
If bodhisattvas see evil people who violate the precepts, they do not give rise to evil thoughts, but devise various skillful means to subdue them;
If they cannot be subdued, they should feel compassion for them and not violate the precepts or abandon the precepts for the sake of their bodies or lives.
After eating, they first cultivate a sense of shame and remorse, a mind of non-negligence, to treat their bodies and lives, as if healing a bad wound.

If they enter a village, it is like entering a forest of sword stakes. They guard their faculties, cultivate right mindfulness, observe what should be done and what should not be done, and do not give rise to negligence.

If a person creates merit, it is also due to me. If a person commits offenses, it is also due to me. Therefore, when I receive great offerings, I should not give rise to joy. When I encounter decline and suffering, I should not give rise to anger.
When receiving little offerings, I should think like this:

Now my faith, precepts, giving, learning, and wisdom abide in accordance with the Dharma to a small degree, so I receive such meager offerings. Therefore, I should not now give rise to thoughts of sorrow and suffering.
I receive the offerings of faith from others for two reasons:
First, to increase others' blessings; second, to increase my own wholesome qualities.
Therefore, if I obtain little or poor things, I should not give rise to distress.
If I stay for a long time and obtain slowly, or if I am despised before obtaining, then I should reproach myself:
This is my past karma, not the fault of sentient beings. Therefore, I should not give rise to distress now.
If, after receiving the precepts, one commits offenses for others, one should also say, 'What is done like this is truly not the way.'
Why is it so?
The twelve divisions of the canon do not say that all evils are the way to enlightenment.
Therefore, I now obtain mixed retribution.
If one is able to deeply contemplate in this way, one should know that this person will be able to fully possess the perfection of morality.

Good man!ğŸ”½If there is a person who is able to restrain the senses and not commit any evil in the four deportments of the body, and is able to endure various sufferings without engaging in wrong livelihood, one should know that this person will be able to fully possess the perfection of morality.

If one gives rise to fear towards the light and heavy precepts, and even when encountering evil times does not violate the minor precepts, and does not allow afflictions to defile the mind, and cultivates patience, one should know that this person will be able to fully possess the perfection of morality.

If one avoids bad friends and causes sentient beings to stay away from evil and wrong views, to know gratitude and repay kindness, one should know that this person can then fully possess the perfection of morality.

If for the sake of good deeds one does not spare one's body or life, dismisses one's own affairs, and accomplishes others' affairs, and upon seeing those who scold and revile one does not give rise to an evil mind, one should know that this person can then fully possess the perfection of morality.

If one sees the places opened up by the TathÄgata and upholds them as they are, protects the lives of sentient beings, does not spare wealth or life, and does not violate even minor precepts until the end of one's life, and although one obtains the subtle seven precious things, one's mind does not give rise to greed, and does not repay kindness by doing good to others, but out of compassion;

Upholds the precepts, and after upholding them, gives rise to great vows, vowing that all sentient beings may attain pure precepts, one should know that this person can then fully possess the perfection of morality.
Good son!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, the lay; second, the monastic.
It is not difficult for a renunciant bodhisattva to be endowed with the perfection of morality;
being endowed with it while living as a householder is difficult.
Why is this?
Because householders are often entangled in many evil conditions.
Chapter 24, Part 1: The Chapter on Karma in the UpÄsaka Precepts SÅ«tra SubhÅ«ti said:
World-Honored One!
When the buddhas and tathÄgatas have not yet appeared in the world, what precepts do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas take?
Good man!

When the Buddha has not yet appeared in the world, at that time there is no refuge in the precepts. There are only wise people who seek the path to enlightenment and cultivate the ten wholesome dharmas.

As for these ten wholesome dharmas, except for the Buddha, no one is able to explain them. The past buddhas spoke of them and they have circulated until now without being lost. The wise ones accept and practice them.
Good man!
Sentient beings who are unable to uphold and cultivate the ten wholesome dharmas are all due to their inability to be close to and serve the Buddha in the past.
Good man!

All sentient beings have mixed minds, and due to the conditions of the mixed mind, there are mixed afflictions. Due to the mixed afflictions, they create mixed karma. Due to the conditions of mixed karma, they experience mixed existence. Due to the conditions of mixed existence, they receive mixed bodies.
Good man!
All sentient beings, having obtained mixed bodies, see mixed colors;
Having seen mixed colors, they give rise to evil thoughts. These evil thoughts are called ignorance.
Ignorance gives rise to the mind of seeking, which is called craving;
What is done due to craving is called karma;
Due to the conditions of this karma, one obtains the fruits of retribution. A wise person can analyze and break through this.
Because of internal afflictions and external conditions, one is then bound;

Having cultivated the ten wholesome deeds, one can be liberated. Therefore, when the TathÄgata first attained supreme perfect enlightenment, he expounded and explained the Dharma of the ten wholesome deeds.

Because of the ten wholesome deeds, there are good and evil conduct, good and evil existences, up to liberation in the world. Therefore, sentient beings should wholeheartedly discern and understand the way of the ten wholesome deeds.
If there are wind and clouds, they hold great water;
